body.p:
Frankfort Ky April 24th 1864
To his Excellency
Thos E. Bramlett
Gov State of Kentucky
Sir

Thinking that you have forgotten me I take this method of recalling to your mind who I am. I take the oath of allegiance at Jonseboro Ill June 13th 1861 and Joined the 18th Illinois Reg't Vols Commandid by Col M. K. Loller for three years if not sooner discharged. Was a recruiting officer with the promise of a commission at the time of my arrest I left the 18th Regt in August 1862 and went to the 8th Tenn with the promise that if I would help to recruit the Reg't that I should receive a commission as 2nd Lieut -- Was in a skirmish near Burkesville Ky and lost my horse and I had to report to my Reg't once every month and my time had almost run out when I should report and to reach my Reg't was compelled to take this horse, but not with the intention of appropriating it to my benefit but to the benefit of the service for a few days with the full intention of returning it to the owner which you know as you was my counsel at the examining trial.

I left my house in the South, came North and take up arms in the service of the "Glorious old Union" which I felt was my duty. And am I to suffer for a thing that my government upholds If you will release me I will return to the service and fight for my country until this rebellion is quelled. My family all live in the Southern
states so I have no chance of writing to them but am here friendless and penniless

p.hi: Hoping you will give me a hearing on this

body.p: I was tried at Columbia Feb 16th 1863 for pressing a horse beloing to Wm Ray's and riding it to any Reg't
Hoping you will give me a hearing on this

I Remain
Your Ob't Servant
J. Standeffer

Adair Cir Ct
